text: A sign featuring the U.S. flag tells us that we're on the premises of "R & D: IMAGINING OUR FUTURE". STAN (twenties) waits. Nervously. A GUARD waits with him. Stan taps instructions into his "Bee", a device he wears a wristwatch. STAN'S GUIDE (a hologram that is his information interface with the world) pops up in front of him, in the form of a SEXY BLONDE, who smiles seductively
Hey Stan.
Messages?
Sorry, sweetie. Stan taps his Bee, and she changes looks and voices as sh continues (he's scrolling through different versions of h Guide):

How 'bout some music while you wait? You love that new cut by -- A door opens. Stan taps his Bee; his Guide disappears. 0 walks in. He's a male android who looks completely human -- like an executive in a business suit: calm, easy self-assured -- except that he's quicker, sleeker, more efficient. His (human) assistant, MANDY, accompanies him. 0 Sorry to keep you waiting, Stan, busy day. 0 nods to the Guard, who leaves. Stan blurts out anxiousl

Listen, I know I blew the last -- 0 We don't expect anybody to get it right all the time, humans aren't capable of that. Stan isn't sure whether this is good or bad...  0 Joke, Stan, loosen up. What we look for is imagination, nobody bats a thousand. I've got good news: we're going to promote you. Stan relaxes: maybe everything is okay. 0 They're going to adjust your retinal scan for security, Mandy will fill you in. If you have any questions, just give me a shout. Mandy opens a door to an anteroom. Stan, heartened, goes through the door. Smells something. Stops, panicked. Turn back -- but the door slams shut. A blinding red light flashes around the door frame. 0 It's the smell that frightens them, we need to work on that.

(making a note) Smells like X bombs -- that kind of sensory-inspired fear is hard to get rid of in us humans -- 0 smiles -- a smile that turns your blood cold. Mandy realizes she's committed a faux-pas -- and is frightened:
Sorry about that "us humans", wasn't thinking. 0 I'm not sensitive, you know that.

I also know you want to be treated as if you're like us. 0 shrugs it off, and strides out, tapping his Bee, which implanted in his wrist: 0 We're coming to look at potential replacements for Stan of the Holloway family --

Welcome to America a few years from now. It doesn't look very different from today. It's much more crowded -- larg buildings hunch up against each other, soaring shafts of steam plume out of buildings and up from beneath the streets -- but everything is organized, clean and emphatically fun: more Disneyland than Blade Runner. The busy masses of people are polite -- if very much in t own worlds, occupied with their Bees and Guides. They pay little attention to (if they notice at all) the sites everywhere. A cafe, a church, the whole front of a building are all being repaired by efficient, partially automated crews. The destruction is hidden by temporary walls, onto which (like the walls of all the buildings) is projected news, entertainment and ads. It's all bright, upbeat and distracting... like this ad:

Upgrade to your new, free Bee 6.0 today and receive TwO THOUSAND free credits, plus fifteen points toward Premiere Status. The Announcer morphs as people pass, their own Bees alter the Announcer's look and voice:

Bee 6 features SenseWorks, our fresh new interface that makes it easier than ever to change your Guide. Don't like blondes? Gone. Want your Guide's voice lower? Your sense is our command. And your own custom images and vocabulary styles are easier than ever to upload. The Bee device in the ad morphs into a smiling honey bee.
Remember, we're your Bee -- but to us, you're always A. A BOY passes the ad. The bee winks at him. He pulls his MOTHER's sleeve:
Mommy mommy, I want it --

A WOMAN IN A LEATHER JACKET AND JEANS (TINA) puts a jar o mayonnaise into her grocery bag and walks out of the stor There's no checker; nowhere to pay. Instead, as she leave her hologram Guide (a studly guy) pops up in front of her
Yo Tina, that's thirty-six bucks, twenty cents. Want to take that outa your general account?
Yeah.

Tina comes upon a BANK that has just been bombed. It's st smoldering, workers are pulling out bodies, and sliding i temporary walls to mask the devastation. Tina is the only passer-by who stops and looks. Her studl Guide tries to distract her:
This branch is closed, babe, there's one at Main and Sixth. Tina peers at the damage inside the bank. Smiles.

Hey Tina, I got real-time video of Michael Jackson being released from prison right this minute! VIDEO of, yes, Michael Jackson getting out of prison is projected from Tina's Bee onto a temporary wall as it is fixed into place, blocking Tina's view of the bombed bank
Tina passes a lamp-post. ZOOM INTO THE LAMP --
Tina goes into the building.

Tina walks into the microscopic one-room apartment. The o window is blacked-out with aluminum foil, which is covere the inside with a something white and gooey. Two other CELL MEMBERS (a MAN dressed as a GARDENER and a TEENAGED BOY) assemble three bombs at the kitchen table.
You get them? Tina takes three metal vials of liquid out of her purse. Hands one to the Gardener, another to the Teenager, and s the third into her pocket. The Teenager starts to open his vial --
(alarmed) Not now! Rattled, the Teenager puts the unopened vial into his poc
0 strides in, trailed by Mandy. TWO ASSISTANTS who have b arguing with each other immediately quiet themselves. 0 So. Replacement for the brother in the Holloway family.

(jumping in quickly) Hank Skinner -- The four walls come alive with surveillance video of HANK (twenties; a normal, worker-bee, upwardly mobile guy -- o that's what he wants to believe; underneath, he's intuiti creative, bright -- but he denies these qualities even to himself, sensing that they are not useful, even suspect).
Smart, funny, loyal, hard worker --
He's risky, his parents were revolutionaries -- members of the so-called Free Republic.  0 Do I detect sarcasm? They had the right to call themselves whatever they liked, it's a free country.

They engaged in illegal acts against the State -- 0 And they failed, nobody remembers anything about them any more, they didn't engage the popular imagination. Not surprising with a name like "Free Republic".
(pointedly, to Second Assistant) Anyway, they're dead. (to 0) Years ago, car accident -- 0 That works for us.
Unless the apple doesn't fall far from the tree. 0 Any sign of revolutionary sympathies?
Hard to say, he keeps his head down.
We'd know. I mean... He gestures to the surveillance info that surrounds them.

But we don't necessarily know, surveillance doesn't tell us everything -- isn't that why we're recruiting these people for R & D? 0 It's about balance. You want them to have initiative, be curious, creative -- but not too much.

And that's why Hank's perfect. This was taken this morning -- The walls display SURVEILLANCE VIDEO shot through windows from satellites, etc. It's much better than back in 2004: crisp and clear, if always from outside.
(A nice but miniscule apartment.) HANK, in his boxers, si beside his bed, drawing on a sketchpad.
Wait till you see this...
The sketch is of his girlfriend VAL, who is asleep in bed Looks just like her -- except that he has drawn her pregn and she doesn't look it.
Val Abbott, they've been together off and on since college, she moved in for the first time five months ago when she lost her job --
Live-in girlfriend, that's a problem. (0.S.)
Or something we can use. Val wakes up. Hanks puts away the sketchpad -- but not qu enough. She reaches for it. He holds it away. She thinks it's a game, tickles Hank to make him let go of the pad:
Come on, let me see -- She sees that he has drawn her pregnant. Freezes.
How'd you know?
(disappointed) Why didn't you tell me?
I just found out yesterday, I was going to but...
Not a good sign, is it? About us. He forces a smile. Gets up and heads to the bathroom.
Photos of Hank's sketches pop up on the wall screens. The uncannily capture the subjects' moods, thoughts, secrets.
He sees people -- perceives who they are, what they want, what they're hiding. Right up our alley.
0 Very promising.

But she's pregnant -- would he be willing to leave her behind? 0 He seems ambivalent, maybe we can take advantage of that if we move fast. Have we got a way into him? INTERCUT WITH SURVEILLANCE VIDEO from the wall screens:
One-room, puny (all the homes are claustrophobic). A sick man (DAVE SKINNER, thirty) stumbles from bed to the bathr
Hank's older brother Dave. Only sibling, no other relatives. Neuroendocrine carcinoma. Stable now but still suffers. 0 He can't afford an SCI? And neither, I suppose, can Hank.
Neither of them are even close to Premiere Status.  0 That's a nice shiny carrot. Other images are projected onto the wall screens: Hank at work, at the gym; out to dinner will Val, on vacations, e
Hank doesn't lose his cool. Anything goes wrong, he sucks it up and keeps everything under control. Doesn't even vote -- seems politically indifferent. A perfect citizen.
Or he's a revolutionary in disguise, keeping a low profile.
There's no sign of that. Also, he's a great match for the Holloway family. He had a strong, creative mother, a preoccupied father, one sibling --
The Holloway matriarch is a grandmother, not a mother, the sibling is a sister, not a brother --
The psychological and emotional dynamics match, the all bode well for an easy adjustment.
I've got some troubling file footage -- A new video file appears on a wall screen:
Hank is out with some BUDDIES, among them DUANE. Differen sports games with odds tickers are broadcast on screens, the guys eagerly place bets with their Bees:
Get it, get it away from -- Catch the ball you -- Duane's Guide, a NAKED BIMBO, pops up:  10.
Hey handsome, that dickhead Palmer just lost you two hundred bucks.
(laughing) You bet on Palmer? Palmer? What's wrong with you? He grabs Duane's arm, slips Duane's Bee off his wrist -- Hank taps
Duane, your Bee's off!
I'll lose points -- ! some instructions into Duane's Bee --
Hey stud, they just docked you twenty Premiere points -- and you were so close to Premiere status --
Hank come on, quit messing -- Hank points his Bee at Duane's bee. Laser communication shoots between them -- Duane's bimbo Guide hiccups and rewinds, then giggles at
Ooo -- you just upgraded, sexy, you're more massive than ever! Welcome to Bee 6.0.
Your bet's erased. Check it out. Hank slips the Bee back on Duane's wrist.
How'd you do that? Hank makes sure nobody's watching, then whispers to Duane
When it was re-writing your software, it wrote over the last two minutes.  11.
0 Lots of people figured out that bug.
Do we want those people working for R & D?
They're exactly the people we need -- resourceful, imaginative --

Anti-establishment? Maybe even revolutionary? I know it's a balancing act finding the right kind of recruit, but we can't keep erring in the wrong direction. 0 That's why I'm here -- androids are much better equipped for risk- assessment than humans. The Second Assistant, chastened, nods. As O heads out: 0 Besides, if he doesn't work out, he can always be promoted.
Hank and Val grab breakfast, moving around each other wit the ease of people who know each other well -- and with t caution of lovers who know the ice is thin:
I got these chem-berries for you.
They're so expensive --
Don't worry about it.
Easy for you to say. He dishes the berries into a bowl for her. End of discuss  12.
. Thanks. (eating them, can't help but smile: ) Remember that trip we took to the coast -- when you could still pick berries for real?
These are sweeter.
(diving in:) I didn't tell you about... that I was pregnant because I didn't want it to be the reason. The reason we split up or stay together. Hank nods, pours ingredients into a blender.
I know you're scared, I'm scared, too --
I'm not scared.
Hank -- let me in for once... Hank turns on the blender. She turns it off.
You know, the world won't come to an end if you let me know how you feel once in a while.
I don't feel things as strong as you do -- He turns the blender back on. She speaks over it:
I see you sketching -- you see things, you feel things most people can't -- how else could you have known I'm --
They're just drawings, they don't mean anything. She turns off the blender:  13.
Just cause your mother was an artist and got in trouble --
This has nothing to do with them.
Then what're you scared of?
I'm not scared. It's just -- the only thing that's private any more is how you feel, it's the only thing that's all yours.
(not what she wanted to hear) You want this baby? Otherwise...
Otherwise what?
.» I don't know. Sanctioned abortions are expensive.
Not like we don't have the money.
I don't -- I don't have a job, I don't have an apartment --
You have here.
Not if we split up.
You can stay here, I've got a job, I've got money, we can do whatever we want.
. So what does that mean, you want to? Get an abortion?
What do you want?  14.
I want to know what you want.
... I don't know. Sorry, really, it's just sudden -- Look, I gotta get to work, we'll talk about it tonight -- okay?
I knew this would screw up everything.
(drawing her close) It'll be okay. Tonight, okay?
captures them kissing goodbye.
watching them on his wall-screen. He gets up briskly.
Tina, the Gardener and the Teenager coat the three bombs the mayonnaise Tina bought at the store, then wrap them i aluminum foil.

-- the new Sierra Spring Surgery Clinic where you'll find a full array of aesthetic services. Skin, height, voice -- you can be everything you want to be, AND you don't even need Premiere Status --

Can I help you?

(tapping his Bee) Get my boss back on the line -- 0 I'm here to offer you a job. (smiling) I'm hoping that my antagonizing your boss will work in my favor.

text: 0 We work with law enforcement agencies --

(skeptical) So it's a government job. 0 We're outsourced. I don't need to tell you it's a dangerous world, Hank. People want law enforcement to be like garbage collection -- just take away the bad stuff, don't make them see it. They don't want to worry, they want us to worry for them.

Hank and O approach the entrance to the park: 0 We've become very efficient at gathering data. We can see and hear pretty much everything we want to. I know more about you than you'd like me to. But. What we can't do is get into people's imaginations. That's where you come in.
I'm not a psychologist or a -- Hank's hologram Guide (PABLO PICASSO) pops up:
Park visit is twenty dollars each hour. 0 Picasso, huh? O waves his imbedded Bee over Hank's wrist-strap Bee.
Most recent charge deleted. 0 It's on the house. Hank's Guide disappears. They walk into the park: 16.  17. 0 Picasso saw into people's souls, you artists do that, you're empathetic to emotions --

I'm not an artist, I just draw people once in a while -- 0 How'd you know your girlfriend was pregnant? Hank gapes at him: How'd he know that? 0 I told you we know more about you than you'd like. How'd you know?
I started sketching her and I -- I guess I saw something -- 0 Exactly: We can't see that.

The park is perfect: clean, sunny, the trees immaculately trimmed, the water antiseptically clean. 0 Look at this park, it's perfect -- too perfect, I'm told. I mean I like it, but then I'm synthetic. It should have been designed by people like you instead of by bureaucrats with computers.
What does this have to do with -- 0 Technology, despite its advances, has no heart. And therefore it can't read hearts. Turns out that's the missing link in the security puzzle.
Look, I'm just a regular guy --  18. 0 You may want to be, but you're not. You can't actually enjoy that job of yours --
It's a good job -- 0 Well, it will be waiting for you if you don't like our job.
I don't get it -- I'd be, what, "imagining" stuff all day? Drawing sketches of terrorists? 0 It's more about elaborating on data.

You've got people trained for that, intelligence officers -- 0 Intelligence, not imagination -- different wiring. We get lots of chatter which we know is important but which defies a logical approach. People like you help us figure out what the bad guys intend.

I don't see how. 0 You will once you start doing it. Whether you know it or not, by sensing what people feel, you can extrapolate motives and thoughts. Everybody we recruit feels the way you do at first. But it works.

So this has been successful? 0 Know how we finally won the war in Syria? We hired some Hollywood screenwriters to imagine what the bad guys would do next. (more)  19. O (cont'd) We can't miss the next attack because we can't imagine what it could be. A child's ball bounces towards them... O snatches it, hurls it at Hank. Hank, startled, catches Without missing a beat, O takes a swing at Hank. Hank instinctively blocks 0's punch with his left arm, without letting go of the ball in his right hand.
0 Ambidextrous.

(what the hell is he doing?) . So what? A LITTLE BOY approaches. 0 hands the ball back to the Boy 0 Careful, you don't want to lose the nice ball, do you? (moving Hank along) Michelangelo was ambidextrous, did you know that? Also Einstein. They did an autopsy on Einstein's brain, he had a much larger profusion of capillaries interlacing the cerebral cortex than average humans. (smiling at Hank's confusion) The two hemispheres of his brain were more evenly balanced -- like yours. You make connections other people can't.

Hank and O return to the entrance: 0 The world is better, safer than it used to be. Lots of people worked hard to make that happen -- your parents in their own way. But there are still many terrorist groups trying to destroy us. We've made your life easy -- shouldn't you give something back?  20.
I see you're programmed for guilt. 0 (laughs) And for bribery -- the job has great benefits: You'll live ina luxurious, spacious house with other members of your family --
Family? 0 We get the best results when these research groups think of themselves as families -- it incubates their potential skills.

I was almost with you, but that's just too weird -- 0 You'll be making five figures weekly, and upgraded immediately to Premiere Status. That should come in handy with things like your brother's illness. Hank gapes at him: this is too creepy. He makes a decisio

Thanks for the offer, but... (shakes his head, no) O hands Hank a card. It reads: "R & D: IMAGINING OUR FUTURE", and there's an embedded code on it. 0 I hope you change your mind. O watches Hank walk away. O's Second Assistant appears on O's Bee:
I've got some other candidates -- 0 Not so fast.
He said no.  21. 0 But I haven't.
Hank and Duane, in sweats, row in a scull on a lake. Hank taps Hank nods.
-- Val's not answering her Bee.
She leave a message for me?
No. You want to leave another message for her?
Yeah -- no --
I'm an artist, I don't have time for this shit. his Bee; his Guide disappears:
I gotta download a new Guide.
Trouble in Val-adise?
No no, everything's cool -- just our usual stuff, you know?
Let me tell you something, buddy, there's nothing better out there.
When're you and Val gonna set me up with that girlfriend of hers? Cause these days it's just my Bee and my right hand, dude.

Yechh. The lake suddenly sputters into a digital mess around the  22. Then it "shuts off", revealing they're actually in an ACTIVITY ROOM AT THE GYM, on a scull machine. The lake wa a virtual projection. Hank's Guide pops up:
Sorry Hank, you're out of credit.
That's impossible --
Want me to try your savings account?
Yeah, I got tons of --
Nothing in that account either.
What? It's got to be a glitch --
Hank strides, talking with a BANK SUPERVISOR projected as hologram in front of him:
Your accounts were withdrawn today at --
But you need the password to do that --
Did anybody else have access to your password? Hank gets really worried, breaks into a run --
The apartment is dark. There's a key in the door, and the soft lights, romantic music, and wall-to-wall sunset imag all switch on automatically. Hank rushes in:
Val?  23. The closet is half-empty. He hurries to the bathroom: Sam thing. Val's gone. He slumps onto the bed, touches her pillow...
Hank's Guide leads Hank through the crowded station --
-- the signal from her Bee places her on the next platform -- Hank follows his Guide onto -- an empty platform.
She's not here.
Yes she is.
No she's not.
Don't yell at me, I'm just a device.
Double-check the --
The signal from her Bee is coming from this location.
(figuring it out) ... She took it off and tossed it here. Oh shit...
Incoming urgent call from Dave.
Hank rushes in to find Dave looking terrible, lying in an cubicle, surrounded by medical devices. It's horrible:
Dave...  24.
So weird, I just fainted. They say it can come back like that.
That sucks.
I'm so sick of always asking you for stuff.
The procedure? Don't worry about it --
Drugs, all that shit, I'm sure I brought this on myself --
That's crazy --
Easy for you to say. Perfect son, perfect health, never a trouble- maker --
So, what, this is my fault?
I didn't say that. It's just -- maybe I should just...
(calling him on it:) What? Maybe you should just what?
Where are you gonna get the money for the procedure?
I'll take that job --
Oh no you won't, Mom and Dad'1l1 curse me from the grave.
So what do you want me to do?
You can't work for the bad guys.  25.
(talking himself into it) Mom and Dad were wrong, Universal Surveillance isn't so bad -- it keeps us safe, right?
You really feel safe?
Sure.
I haven't felt safe a minute of my life since they died. (admiring him) Somehow you got their... bigness, their steadiness.
Come on --
You come on -- don't pretend you didn't, not now.
(seeing it means so much to him: ) . Okay.

Even when you were a kid -- Mom'd be finger-painting with you, I'd turn up the TV loud, but she wouldn't even look at me, not even to tell me to turn it down. She'd stand behind you, tell you to concentrate, not listen to the TV, just zone it out and concentrate on whatever you were painting. She'd put her hands over yours and you paint together.
How do you remember this? I don't even remember it --

The fridge was plastered with your shit. (more)  26. DAVE (cont'd) One of your finger-paintings, a sunflower, your masterpiece, it stayed there till... (then) I'm just so scared, man. Hank grabs Dave's hand:
You're gonna be okay.
Hank, deep in thought, walks up the steps of The Uni-Chur

You've been approved, ten percent interest per week.
Hank walks in. A digital sign lists CHURCH ONE, TWO, THRE etc., each designated OCCUPIED or AVAILABLE.

Sermon?

whose phone rings. O leans back, relieved. Wipes sweat of his upper lip -- not very Android-like behavior. He smiles and answers the phone.

(ignoring her, to Hank) So we understand you're an artist? Very impressive.

I'm a writer -- you've probably never heard of me: Frank Jackson?
Frank Jackson, the spy thrillers?
Publishers thought they'd sell better with a male name.
But your books are so... (stops himself)
Masculine? I was in military intelligence. When they put me out to pasture, I took up writing.  32.
She gives most of her royalties to the National Rifle Association. Seriously.

Well we can't all be bohemians. GILMAN HOLLOWAY (forties) comes downstairs, carrying a to Flash Gordon-type weapon. He's passionate about the work, but the passion hides a dark anger and fear underneath:

(to Hank) Sorry to be late -- Gilman Holloway -- I'm the "Dad". I was up all night with this -- He points the toy weapon at a wall and FIRES IT. There's a nearly silent BLAST -- but when the smoke clear the wall looks unchanged.
I've had nights like that. Gilman sticks his hand through where he fired: that part the wall has been blasted away, replaced by a hologram of wall the way it was.

(quietly) Was it Amy's? (off Gilman's nod, to Hank) This was Gilman's house, his kid sister Amy was killed by terrorists.
And he's done an excellent job of moving on.

Shall we "move on" into the family room?
The Gardener (the male Cell Member), works on a planter - hiding in it the plastic bag containing the last bomb. Th image FREEZES, and we're in:

XRAY SHOTS ZOOM IN ON THE purse, locker and plastic bag, revealing black blobs inside -- As 0 briefs the family (Hank, Susanna, Mrs. Jackson and Gilman) via a holographic video hook-up: 0 We've been tracking Tina Falk's cell for several days, no apparent connections to other terrorist groups.
There are so many out there.  34. 0 We believe these devices to be bombs, but they've somehow disguised them so we can't get visuals. Of course, that makes them suspicious in and of itself --
Why haven't you arrested them? Or picked up those bombs?
‘Cause the bombs are decoys, right? Look at her body language -- She imitates Tina, as surveillance video showing Tina planting her purse in the office is projected on the wall

She's putting on a show -- making sure she's not blocking a surveillance camera, opening the drawer more than necessary so we can see inside. It's like she wants surveillance to see her. 0 Exactly. What we need you to figure out is, Why plant decoys? What are they trying to distract us from?
